Class AbstractCurve

  • java.lang.Object
    • main.AbstractCurve
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, Curve

    public abstract class AbstractCurve
extends java.lang.Object
implements Curve
    Extension of Curve with some useful methods added
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    EPICI
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      AbstractCurve() 

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      double[] bake(double l, double r, int n)
      Sample n equally spaced points in the range [l, r) such that the first point is at l and the n+1th point, if it existed, would be at r
      This is not numerically stable, but is fine for any reasonable parameters
      Provided here only because certain subclasses cannot gain any performance advantage with code tailored to them
      double[] sample(double[] positions)
      Sample some number of points
      Provided here only because certain subclasses cannot gain any performance advantage with code tailored to them

    • Method Detail

      • sample

        public double[] sample(double[] positions)
        Sample some number of points
        Provided here only because certain subclasses cannot gain any performance advantage with code tailored to them
        Parameters:
        positions - x values to sample
        Returns:
        y value for each x

      • bake

        public double[] bake(double l,
                     double r,
                     int n)
        Sample n equally spaced points in the range [l, r) such that the first point is at l and the n+1th point, if it existed, would be at r
        This is not numerically stable, but is fine for any reasonable parameters
        Provided here only because certain subclasses cannot gain any performance advantage with code tailored to them
        Parameters:
        l - first value as described above
        r - would-be last value as described above
        n - number of sample points as described above
        Returns:
        y value for each sampled x in the range
